festivalInfo.title: Khajuraho Dance Festival
festivalInfo.organizer: Madhya Pradesh Tourism & Department of Culture

taglines: A RICH TRADITION OF INDIA WITH YOUTH OF INDIA 2026
A Week of India's Living Traditions

events.bio: Grand inauguration with traditional lamp lighting ceremony and welcome performances.
Nora Fatehi is a Canadian dancer and actress based in India. She has appeared in Hindi, Telugu, and Malayalam films.
Disciples of the legendary Pandit Birju Maharaj presenting traditional Lucknow gharana Kathak.
Renowned choreographer and judge known for popularizing contemporary dance in India. Won American Choreography Award for Lagaan and trained at Alvin Ailey and Martha Graham centers in New York.
Sangeet Natak Akademi awardee, preserving the delicate grace of Manipuri Ras Lila traditions.
Padma Shri awardee known as the 'Indian Michael Jackson'. Two-time National Film Award winner for Best Choreography, trained in Bharatanatyam and known for iconic dance sequences in Indian cinema.
Padma Shri awardee and Bollywood icon, professionally trained in Kathak for 8 years. Six-time Filmfare Award winner known as the 'Dhak Dhak Girl', celebrated for her exceptional dancing abilities.
Legendary 'Shahenshah of Bollywood' with Padma Vibhushan and Dadasaheb Phalke Award. Four-time National Film Award winner with over 200 films, known as the 'Angry Young Man' of Indian cinema.
Two-time National Film Award winner and Bollywood superstar. Founder of Being Human Foundation, known for blockbusters like Bajrangi Bhaijaan, Sultan, and the Tiger franchise.
Contemporary Kathak pioneer blending traditional grammar with modern themes and expressions.
Padma Shri awardee known for her solo productions exploring contemporary themes.
Special collaborative performance blending classical and modern dance vocabularies.
Platform for emerging talents from various dance academies across India.
Padma Shri recipient and founding director of Gandharva Mahavidyalaya's dance wing.
Dynamic Kathak performer known for his powerful footwork and innovative presentations.
Padma Shri awardee and founder of Natya Vriksha, promoting Bharatanatyam globally.
Jaipur gharana maestro known for preserving traditional compositions and techniques.
Special preview performance featuring highlights from the week's best moments.
Recognition ceremony honoring outstanding performances and contributions.
Spectacular closing performance featuring all major artists from the festival week.
Traditional closing with aarti and vote of thanks, marking the end of a glorious week.

danceForms.name: Bharatanatyam
danceForms.description: Ancient temple dance form known for its geometric patterns and expressive storytelling.

danceForms.name: Kathak
danceForms.description: Storytelling dance with intricate footwork and graceful spins from Mughal courts.

danceForms.name: Odissi
danceForms.description: Temple dance characterized by fluid movements and sculptural poses.

danceForms.name: Kuchipudi
danceForms.description: Dynamic dance-drama tradition with both solo and group performances.

danceForms.name: Manipuri
danceForms.description: Devotional dance form known for its gentle, lyrical movements.

danceForms.name: Kathakali
danceForms.description: Dramatic art form with elaborate costumes, makeup, and facial expressions.

danceForms.name: Mohiniyattam
danceForms.description: Graceful feminine dance form depicting enchanting movements.

danceForms.name: Sattriya
danceForms.description: Monastic dance tradition originating from Vaishnavite monasteries.

weather.description: Pleasant winter weather, ideal for outdoor events
weather.recommendation: Light woolens for evenings, comfortable cotton for daytime

faqs.question: Is entry to the festival free?
faqs.answer: Yes, entry to the Khajuraho Dance Festival is free. However, registration is recommended for seat allocation and updates about the schedule.

faqs.question: What time do performances start?
faqs.answer: Performances typically begin at sunset, around 6:00-6:30 PM, and continue until 9:30-10:00 PM each evening.

faqs.question: Is photography allowed?
faqs.answer: Photography is allowed during performances, but flash photography may be restricted. Please follow announcements made during the event.

faqs.question: What should I wear?
faqs.answer: Smart casual or traditional Indian attire is appropriate. Evenings can be cool, so bring a light jacket or shawl.

faqs.question: Are there seating arrangements?
faqs.answer: Open-air seating is provided on a first-come-first-served basis. VIP seating may be available through special registration.

faqs.question: Is the venue wheelchair accessible?
faqs.answer: The venue has some accessibility provisions. Please contact organizers in advance for special assistance requirements.

faqs.question: Are food and beverages available?
faqs.answer: Food stalls and refreshment counters are available near the venue. Local cuisine and snacks are offered.

faqs.question: Can children attend?
faqs.answer: Yes, the festival is family-friendly. Children of all ages are welcome, though late evening performances may not be suitable for very young children.
